message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is consistent with a basal cell carcinoma. The lesion has not grown in size but it has central ulceration and curled borders which can suggest local invasion via collagenase. Basal cell carcinomas are typically locally invasive rather than prone to metastasis, therefore options A and D can be ruled out. Option B is not correct because basal cell carcinoma can become aggressive and invade surrounding tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical and histopathological findings suggest that the lesion is a basal cell carcinoma (BCC). BCCs are typically slow-growing and have low metastatic potential. The most common mode of spread of BCCs is local invasion via collagenase, which allows the tumor cells to break down the surrounding collagen and invade surrounding tissues. Seeding is an uncommon mode of spread for BCCs. Lymphatic spread is relatively rare, occurring in only about 5% of cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lesion and histopathology findings suggest basal cell carcinoma. It is usually localized and does not spread to distant sites or lymph nodes. Local invasion via collagenase is the most common mode of spread for basal cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lesion and histopathological findings suggest a basal cell carcinoma, which is a malignant tumor that does not typically spread through seeding or lymphatic spread. Local invasion via collagenase is a characteristic of basal cell carcinoma, and it can invade the surrounding tissues and organs, which can lead to disfigurement or functional impairments if left untreated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lesion, along with the histopathology findings, suggests that the most likely diagnosis is basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinoma commonly spreads locally via collagenase, which breaks down collagen in the extracellular matrix to facilitate invasion of tumor cells into surrounding tissue. It is typically a slow-growing and non-metastasizing tumor, so options (A) and (D) can be ruled out. Option (B) is also not correct as basal cell carcinoma can become invasive and cause local destruction if left untreated.

Basal cell carcinomas are typically slow-growing and do not metastasize beyond the primary site, so options A and D are incorrect. Option B is incorrect because the lesion has been bleeding, indicating a more aggressive behavior.

It has a low rate of metastasis and does not typically spread via lymphatic or hematogenous routes. Seeding is also not a common mode of spread for this type of neoplasm.

The description of the lesion and histopathology suggest that the patient has a basal cell carcinoma, which is a type of skin cancer that does not typically spread via lymphatics or seeding. Local invasion via collagenase is the most common mode of spread for basal cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s lesion had a pearly appearance with telangiectasia and central ulceration and curled borders, which suggests a possible diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma. The histopathology finding of peripheral palisading cells with large, hyperchromatic nuclei and a high nuclear: cytoplasmic ratio, confirms this diagnosis. Basal cell carcinomas typically invade via collagenase leading to local invasion rather than spreading through lymphatic or hematogenous routes. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) Local invasion via collagenase.
